children.value: 2 Biggest Limitations of Labels & Filters in Todoist
Sometimes I need to refer to a series of related labels in a filter. Let’s imagine that certain tasks you do have to be done in a certain location.
you have to be at your
you can’t pickup your kids from your
unless you have an app, you need to go to a
To address these concerns, you create a few labels:
Let’s imagine you want to see any tasks which do
have a location label specified. Here’s how that filter query would look:

hProperties.aria-label: new filter no location specified permalink

children.value: Check for tasks without location specified

So far, so good. Personally, I have 13 location labels. But let’s imagine you kept it to these three examples. Every time you wanted to check whether you’ve added a location label to your tasks, you would have to check all three of these labels.
This is probably fine, but now let’s assume you want to create a new filter.

hProperties.aria-label: new filter now   house   work permalink

children.value: flag system seems like a remnant from agile which is ill-suited to general purposes project management given that Todoist uses it to influence the order in which tasks are rendered. The reason this ordering matters is that it directly impacts how tasks are grouped. Imagine that you have a “level 1” priority task that isn’t due until the evening. The entire day it’s highlighted in red at the top. There’s unnecessary cognitive cost here. You end up reading over the same lines multiple times even though you have no intention of using them.
Now, your filter would look like this:
Again, this isn’t so bad. But what happens when you want to see tasks which have been categorized but have not been prioritized? How about

new filter categorized  location   not prioritized permalink

Great. After you update those labels, you’ll notice that the labels update across every task. But wait, you’re not out of the woods yet ! You have to also update every.single.filter which relies on these labels.
You can create a superset label (which is what I do), like so:
, I can check a single label and determine whether those child-labels exist. This is incredibly useful in a number of places.
The unfortunate side effect of this temporary workaround is: I have to create “reconciliation” filters (

This is quite tedious, but these reconciliation filters are preferred to the alternative: not having a superset label which I can easily check.

Surely there has to be a better way, right?
Absolutely! All of this tedium could be solved easily by allowing
With wildcards there would be no need for superset labels or reconciliation filters whatsoever. For the sake of consistency, though, let’s look at that
reconciliation filter again with wildcards supported in Filters:
When renaming labels, update all instances of those labels in filters (just like all labels are already automatically updated across tasks)
